captions.text: Hey, do you want to watch these video a week early
and can&#39;t go to The Escapist site because you are violently allergic to ads?
Well, now The Escapist has YouTube memberships and a new Escapist Plus premium service; either of which,
can provide what you need along side other bonuses like emojis and badges and a chance to join in
regular Q &amp; A videos. There&#39;s also new t-shirts available for sale on Teespring! I wan&#39;t sure how to segue to that.

So as is well documented Animal Crossing New
Horizons came out the same day as Doom Eternal,

cue lots of Photoshops of THE DOOM SLAYER
chasing Lost Souls with a butterfly net, lollety

lol, memety meme, but the two are a weirdly
good pairing. What better way to unwind from

a high tension gameplay experience than with
something cheerful, relaxing and colourful

like Doom Eternal yeah you figured out where
this joke was going half a sentence ago I&#39;m

sure. Now that Nintendo have got this whole
console thing down a version of Animal Crossing

for the Switch was inevitable. Animal Crossing
is an institution at this point, one that

requires commitment, and as such I thoroughly
recommend it to anyone who thinks they&#39;re

ready to be commited to an institution. The
setup this time around is that you and the

predatory raccoon loan shark Tom Nook have
come to a desert island wilderness in order

to develop it into yet another wholesome capitalist
paradise for animal-shaped random number generators.

You know, the kind of setup where, if it were
a film, you&#39;d expect half the cast to be cannibalised

by the end of act two, but don&#39;t worry, Tom
Nook presumably massacred the native island

population before we arrived. The process
of developing the island largely entails for

your part the transfer of ungodly amounts
of Bells from you to Tom Nook&#39;s holdings account,

and the usual Animal Crossing routine quickly
sets in.

You fish, you catch bugs, you acquire furniture,
you sell it all to Tom Nook for money that

you then use to pay off your loans to Tom
Nook. It&#39;s the all-Tom Nook economy. When

Tom Nook dies, this entire society will fucking
collapse into anarchy where brightly coloured

animal people shiv each other for pears. And
as always you&#39;re expected to come back every

day in real time to pull the weeds, dig up
a new set of fossils and defuse any shiv-based

arguments. Very little that I didn&#39;t already
comment on the last time my path was crossing

with Animal... game. With the animal game.
But I managed to gain a new perspective on

Animal Tossing this time around by introducing
my wife to it. Now, be warned before you show

your significant other or cohabitant Animal
Crossing that it&#39;s a risky play. On the one

hand, they won&#39;t yell at you to stop playing
video games for a while, but on the other,

the house will rot and the children will starve.
I&#39;m ashamed to admit that I knew Animal Crossing

would suck her in because she&#39;s one of those
100% completion types who have always ensured

that Pokemon makes bank like a 7-11 across
the road from a marijuana shop.

So on day 1 she was saying she probably wouldn&#39;t
be into it and by day 5 she was staying up

fishing long into the night &#39;cos she had to
catch just one fucking sturgeon before the

end of March. And by day 8 she was digging
holes in a series of arcane patterns in the

hope of summoning a tarantula to catch and
I began to worry that she might have joined

a cargo cult. But I was gathering all kinds
of interesting data on the communal experience

of Animal Crossing. For example, kids, the
first of your siblings who gets to play Animal

Crossing New Horizons is officially the one
your parents love the most. The first player

gets a fun little sequence where they camp
out with Tom Nook and get gently tutorialised

and get to name the island and pick where
all the characters&#39; houses go so they can

start a beaver ghetto if they feel so inclined,
and the next player to join on the same Switch

gets &quot;Oh, hello, you&#39;re here too. Here are
some old twigs we found, try not to get them

dirty. What&#39;s that? You&#39;d like to have your
own island to play with? Well, you see that

dung beetle over there? You see how he&#39;s eating
shit? I think you could learn a lot from his example.&quot;

There&#39;s this whole new system of etiquette
one must adhere to when other people in the

household are playing Animal Crossing. Is
the first person to log on that day duty bound

to dig up all the fossils? If my cohabitee
sends me a hat they designed, is a token thank

you reply enough or am I obliged to wear the
awful fucking thing? If they spent hours grinding

fish bait trying to catch a blue Marlin and
I catch one entirely by chance on my first

go, how many is an inappropriate number of
pelvic thrusts to do in their stupid crying

face? And so on. As for how New Horizons compares
to previous incarnations, there&#39;s a greater

sense in this one that the environment is
growing and developing as time goes on. At

first it&#39;s all tents and temporary housing,
no shop, no museum and most of it&#39;s locked

behind impassable rivers and cliffs, but with
time, several large payments to Tom Nook and

enough inevitable fucking crafting to soak
up more PVA glue than any unsupervised schoolchild

could consume in a lifetime you gradually
turn this mysterious exotic wilderness into

yet another Animal Crossing consumerist hellhole
identical to the last one. Tom Nook is the

living embodiment of the gray goo scenario.
You could call the development of the island

the game&#39;s story campaign if you want, much
as that would be like putting a dead dog on
a swing and calling it an adventure playground.

But that might be missing the point, because
the point of Animal Crossing is that there

is no point. Oh, there&#39;re plenty of overt
challenges you can distract yourself with

- get all of the fish, get all of the furniture,
make all the animal people dress up in Swastika

patterned jumpers - but all that matters is
that you ARE distracted. Now, obviously Nintendo

didn&#39;t know a pandemic and global lockdown
was going to happen, and I&#39;m certainly not

saying they orchestrated it alongside a shadowy
cabal of global corporations to reaffirm their

grip on power - to reiterate I am NOT saying
that, Nintendo, you can stop sending the frighteners

round, now - but Animal Crossing couldn&#39;t
have come out at a better time, because it

offers something that is sorely needed - stability.
Keep hold of your Nintendo Switch through

every water war and bandit raid in the coming
years and you will always have a little place

that will never change, where the grass is
always green and the peaches always look like

tiny pairs of perfect buttocks. And where
the owl at the museum always says the exact

same nineteen fucking lines of dialogue when
I just want him to assess some fucking fossils
and shut his fucking face.

But do you like Animal Crossing New Horizons,
Yahtzee? See, that&#39;s the wrong question. Of

course I don&#39;t. But I still play it. It&#39;s
full of little annoyances I could nitpick

about, but I strongly suspect it&#39;s the flaws
that make it absorbing. Of course smacking

rocks doesn&#39;t just drop crafting resources,
it has to parcel them out based on how many

times you can smack it in ten seconds so you
feel motivated to try and beat that record.

Of course we can&#39;t skip the interminably repetitive
dialogue and fish puns, because our eventual

payout from the morning&#39;s fishing will be
all the sweeter for having put in the slog.

Of course the owl always says the same fucking
thing, because if they said something different

for once we&#39;d all be struck with terror at
the sudden injection of chaos into our ordered

little world, the way a suburban community
reacts when a black person moves in. And annoying

as it is that there&#39;s only so much you can
do until you have to wait another day, it&#39;s

well documented that that&#39;s how these games
turn into habits. If you set out to masturbate

once a day, within about two weeks you&#39;re
not even doing it because you want to anymore.

You&#39;re all like &quot;Well, what can I do? Hands
tied! It&#39;s wank o&#39;clock.&quot;
